newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Tatra Banka rates Nafta shares as long-term buy.
newsitem.headline: Tatra Banka rates Nafta shares as long-term buy.

text.p: Shares of oil and gas storage company Nafta Gbely are undervalued compared to its competitors in East Europe and are a good long-term buy, Tatra Banka said in an investor report.
The bank forecast Nafta's after-tax profit to fall to around 450 million crowns in 1996, some 25 percent less than the previous year, due to lower gas prices and storage fees.
"We do not expect radical changes in the (profit) development this year, but we still consider the share good for long-term investment," the report said.
The report said Nafta's 800 million crown investment programme to increase storage capacity and diversification of gas supplies should increase profit margins in coming years.
"Nafta shares are undervalued in terms of their price to earnings ratio, forecast at 10.8 in 1997, compared with similar companies in the region," the report said.
Nafta's price has been hovering around 1,600 crowns over the past few months, closing at 1,650 on the Bratislava Stock Exchange on Thursday.

Nafta shares fell by over 20 percent in the second half of last year after the government sold its entire stake of 45.9 percent to little-known company Druha Obchodna for 500 million crowns, while the value of the stake at the BSE was some 3.2 billion crowns.
Analysts have said Nafta's new owners have so far said little about their long-term strategy, which has put off foreign investors, but the report said it expected little change.
"We expect the new owners will continue with Nafta's long-term commercial strategy so the current price then is a good opportunity to accumulate profits."
